meta.title: The Indicator from Planet Money
meta.description: A little show about big ideas. From the people who make Planet Money, The Indicator helps you make sense of what's happening today. It's a quick hit of insight into work, business, the economy, and everything else. Listen weekday afternoons.
meta.author: NPR
meta.summary: A little show about big ideas. From the people who make Planet Money, The Indicator helps you make sense of what's happening today. It's a quick hit of insight into work, business, the economy, and everything else. Listen weekday afternoons.

episodes.title: The Public Transit Problem
episodes.description: Public transit systems are vital to cities. Many have been shut down or slowed during the pandemic. Now city administrators have to figure out how to reopen them.
episodes.summary: Public transit systems are vital to cities. Many have been shut down or slowed during the pandemic. Now city administrators have to figure out how to reopen them.

episodes.title: Small Banks' Corona Crunch
episodes.description: Many banks have changed the way they work, as they hurry to get billions in CARES Act cash to small businesses.
episodes.summary: Many banks have changed the way they work, as they hurry to get billions in CARES Act cash to small businesses.

episodes.title: Waiting For A Check
episodes.description: State unemployment offices have been slammed, as 36 million Americans have lost their jobs. And now individuals and the U.S. economy are depending on these often underfunded operations to step up.
episodes.summary: State unemployment offices have been slammed, as 36 million Americans have lost their jobs. And now individuals and the U.S. economy are depending on these often underfunded operations to step up.

episodes.title: Reopening Sports: Does MMA Point The Way?
episodes.description: Mixed martial arts is the first major spectator sport in the U.S. to host live events since the coronavirus lockdown. Other sports are watching to see whether MMA could point the way.
episodes.summary: Mixed martial arts is the first major spectator sport in the U.S. to host live events since the coronavirus lockdown. Other sports are watching to see whether MMA could point the way.

episodes.title: Coronavirus, Farmworkers And America's Food Supply
episodes.description: The working conditions on many farms mean that agricultural laborers are at high risk of getting COVID-19. That poses a real threat to those workers and to the country's food supply.
episodes.summary: The working conditions on many farms mean that agricultural laborers are at high risk of getting COVID-19. That poses a real threat to those workers and to the country's food supply.

episodes.title: Pay Cuts Vs. Layoffs
episodes.description: Companies hammered by the economic collapse due to the coronavirus pandemic are being forced to make a hard choice: lay staff off or cut their pay.
episodes.summary: Companies hammered by the economic collapse due to the coronavirus pandemic are being forced to make a hard choice: lay staff off or cut their pay.

episodes.title: On Demand
episodes.description: The U.S. economy depends on consumer demand. And demand is way down because of the coronavirus pandemic. What happens if it doesn't come back?
episodes.summary: The U.S. economy depends on consumer demand. And demand is way down because of the coronavirus pandemic. What happens if it doesn't come back?

episodes.title: A Brutal Jobs Report
episodes.description: The jobs report for this month was nightmarish. But as bad as it was, it hid some even worse news about the employment situation.
episodes.summary: The jobs report for this month was nightmarish. But as bad as it was, it hid some even worse news about the employment situation.

episodes.title: Gov. Newsom On Reopening California
episodes.description: California Governor Gavin Newsom talks with Stacey Vanek Smith about his plans to reopen the fifth largest economy in the world.
episodes.summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom talks with Stacey Vanek Smith about his plans to reopen the fifth largest economy in the world.

episodes.title: Masks En Vogue
episodes.description: If the pandemic goes on much longer, or its aftereffects linger, face masks will inevitably become a fashion accessory.
episodes.summary: If the pandemic goes on much longer, or its aftereffects linger, face masks will inevitably become a fashion accessory.

episodes.title: Italy Reopens: A Tale of Two Bookstores
episodes.description: Italy was one of the countries hardest hit by coronavirus, and was one of the first to shut down its economy. Now it's reopening. But not everyone's happy about it.
episodes.summary: Italy was one of the countries hardest hit by coronavirus, and was one of the first to shut down its economy. Now it's reopening. But not everyone's happy about it.

episodes.title: The Workplace In The COVID-19 Era
episodes.description: As businesses make plans to reopen their workplaces, we're probably going to find that these spaces will look very different than before.
episodes.summary: As businesses make plans to reopen their workplaces, we're probably going to find that these spaces will look very different than before.

episodes.title: Creating A Post Pandemic World
episodes.description: We're all thinking about what the world might look like after this pandemic. Several years ago, Justin Marks had a vision of how things might be, in his TV show, Counterpart.
episodes.summary: We're all thinking about what the world might look like after this pandemic. Several years ago, Justin Marks had a vision of how things might be, in his TV show, Counterpart.

episodes.title: Essential Workers
episodes.description: Essential workers put themselves at risk of infection every day to keep the economy running. But many aren't well protected or compensated for the dangerous work they do.
episodes.summary: Essential workers put themselves at risk of infection every day to keep the economy running. But many aren't well protected or compensated for the dangerous work they do.

episodes.title: Getting Back To Business
episodes.description: Small and medium size enterprises tend not to have much of a cash cushion, so most are desperate to get back to work. But many are finding that reopening after a pandemic is a messy business.
episodes.summary: Small and medium size enterprises tend not to have much of a cash cushion, so most are desperate to get back to work. But many are finding that reopening after a pandemic is a messy business.

episodes.title: Disease In A Globalized World
episodes.description: Globalization and urbanization historically have made the global economy more productive and efficient — and also more vulnerable to pandemics. But now they can be forces for good in the fight against disease.
episodes.summary: Globalization and urbanization historically have made the global economy more productive and efficient — and also more vulnerable to pandemics. But now they can be forces for good in the fight against disease.

episodes.title: The Bankruptcy Question
episodes.description: The COVID-19 pandemic is driving thousands of people and businesses into bankruptcy.
episodes.summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is driving thousands of people and businesses into bankruptcy.

episodes.title: How The Fed Fights Coronavirus
episodes.description: Much has been made of the unprecedented legislation passed by Congress in its attempt to curtail the economic damage of COVID-19. But what about the Federal Reserve?
episodes.summary: Much has been made of the unprecedented legislation passed by Congress in its attempt to curtail the economic damage of COVID-19. But what about the Federal Reserve?

episodes.title: The Great Potato Giveaway
episodes.description: Supermarket shelves are empty, and food banks around the country are besieged. So why are farmers dumping, destroying and giving away food?
episodes.summary: Supermarket shelves are empty, and food banks around the country are besieged. So why are farmers dumping, destroying and giving away food?

episodes.title: Why We Didn't Prepare For The Pandemic
episodes.description: We've had plenty of warnings over the years that we weren't ready for a pandemic. Today on the show: the psychology and economics of why.
episodes.summary: We've had plenty of warnings over the years that we weren't ready for a pandemic. Today on the show: the psychology and economics of why.

episodes.title: Oil: Less Than Zero
episodes.description: The price of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate crude oil fell below zero. In other words, suppliers were paying people to take it off their hands. How did that happen? And what does it mean?
episodes.summary: The price of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate crude oil fell below zero. In other words, suppliers were paying people to take it off their hands. How did that happen? And what does it mean?

episodes.title: Coronavirus And The Digital Divide
episodes.description: We're spending more time at home, and more time with technology — highlighting a deep digital divide in the United States and introducing thorny ethical dilemmas.
episodes.summary: We're spending more time at home, and more time with technology — highlighting a deep digital divide in the United States and introducing thorny ethical dilemmas.

episodes.title: Where's My Stimulus Check?
episodes.description: Sending $1,200 checks to millions of Americans was a big part of the aid bill Congress passed last month. Around 80 million Americans got that money this week. But 60 million are still waiting.
episodes.summary: Sending $1,200 checks to millions of Americans was a big part of the aid bill Congress passed last month. Around 80 million Americans got that money this week. But 60 million are still waiting.

episodes.title: Small Businesses On Their Own
episodes.description: Congress' recent aid package directed $370 billion to help small businesses. The fund is out of money, and it seems very few who applied got help.
episodes.summary: Congress' recent aid package directed $370 billion to help small businesses. The fund is out of money, and it seems very few who applied got help.

episodes.title: Performing After A Pandemic
episodes.description: Live performance has always been a risky business, run on thin margins. The COVID-19 pandemic has ratcheted up that risk and sharpened those margins to a razor's edge.
episodes.summary: Live performance has always been a risky business, run on thin margins. The COVID-19 pandemic has ratcheted up that risk and sharpened those margins to a razor's edge.

episodes.title: Rural Hospitals: The Waiting Game
episodes.description: Rural hospitals already walk a scalpel's edge between solvency and collapse. Coronavirus threatens to push many of them over the brink.
episodes.summary: Rural hospitals already walk a scalpel's edge between solvency and collapse. Coronavirus threatens to push many of them over the brink.

episodes.title: The Story So Far
episodes.description: Five indicators provide a gauge of how daily economic life in America has changed.
episodes.summary: Five indicators provide a gauge of how daily economic life in America has changed.

episodes.title: Why Hospitals Are Laying People Off
episodes.description: Hospitals are ramping up and gathering supplies to deal with a deluge of coronavirus patients. At the same time, revenues are down. All of this means hospitals across the U.S. are laying off workers.
episodes.summary: Hospitals are ramping up and gathering supplies to deal with a deluge of coronavirus patients. At the same time, revenues are down. All of this means hospitals across the U.S. are laying off workers.

episodes.title: Why Sweden Isn't Locking Down
episodes.description: Most of the world's developed economies have gone on total economic lockdown to combat coronavirus. Sweden has kept its economy open. Sweden says this is better for the economy and for public health.
episodes.summary: Most of the world's developed economies have gone on total economic lockdown to combat coronavirus. Sweden has kept its economy open. Sweden says this is better for the economy and for public health.

episodes.title: Coronavirus and Trade
episodes.description: The coronavirus pandemic may have pushed trade wars off the front page, but such wars are still with us — and they're complicating the world's ability to fight the virus.
episodes.summary: The coronavirus pandemic may have pushed trade wars off the front page, but such wars are still with us — and they're complicating the world's ability to fight the virus.

episodes.title: Coronavirus And The Gig Economy
episodes.description: Many gig workers have suddenly found themselves providing essential services during the COVID-19 pandemic. But many also feel like they have to work in an unsafe situation.
episodes.summary: Many gig workers have suddenly found themselves providing essential services during the COVID-19 pandemic. But many also feel like they have to work in an unsafe situation.

episodes.title: Pandemic-onomics: Lessons From The Spanish Flu
episodes.description: Different cities responded in different ways to the Spanish Flu outbreak of 1918. And their economies fared differently as a result.
episodes.summary: Different cities responded in different ways to the Spanish Flu outbreak of 1918. And their economies fared differently as a result.

episodes.title: The Jobs Crisis
episodes.description: We had almost a decade of growth in the jobs market. But in the last two weeks, nearly 10 million people lost their jobs. Today, we look at the labor market — what's happening and where it's headed.
episodes.summary: We had almost a decade of growth in the jobs market. But in the last two weeks, nearly 10 million people lost their jobs. Today, we look at the labor market — what's happening and where it's headed.

episodes.title: The Coronavirus Pivot
episodes.description: Faced with the prospect of shutting up shop because of coronavirus, some companies are retooling and pivoting to keep their doors open and their workers employed.
episodes.summary: Faced with the prospect of shutting up shop because of coronavirus, some companies are retooling and pivoting to keep their doors open and their workers employed.

episodes.title: Three Ideas To Fight The Recession
episodes.description: Policymakers can still do more to fight the coronavirus recession. Here are three ideas that we haven't yet tried.
episodes.summary: Policymakers can still do more to fight the coronavirus recession. Here are three ideas that we haven't yet tried.

episodes.title: Scarcity In The Emergency Room
episodes.description: Emergency rooms all over the country are struggling with limited resources: masks, ventilators, hospital beds, doctors. We talk to one ER doctor in New York about how she is managing those resources right now.
episodes.summary: Emergency rooms all over the country are struggling with limited resources: masks, ventilators, hospital beds, doctors. We talk to one ER doctor in New York about how she is managing those resources right now.

episodes.title: Listeners Ask, We Answer
episodes.description: Coronavirus questions on the yield curve and refinancing. And some of the ways individuals can help.
episodes.summary: Coronavirus questions on the yield curve and refinancing. And some of the ways individuals can help.

episodes.title: When Should We Restart the Economy?
episodes.description: President Trump got major backlash this week when he suggested businesses should reopen by Easter. Critics said that was way too early. How do we know when it's safe for businesses to reopen?
episodes.summary: President Trump got major backlash this week when he suggested businesses should reopen by Easter. Critics said that was way too early. How do we know when it's safe for businesses to reopen?

episodes.title: The Labor Market Catastrophe
episodes.description: Layoffs and furloughs due to the coronavirus clampdown have pushed 3.3 million Americans to apply for unemployment benefits, the largest weekly increase in U.S. history.
episodes.summary: Layoffs and furloughs due to the coronavirus clampdown have pushed 3.3 million Americans to apply for unemployment benefits, the largest weekly increase in U.S. history.

episodes.summary: The Senate has managed to negotiate a $2 trillion relief package to help keep the U.S. economy afloat as we deal with the coronavirus pandemic. What's in it and will it be enough?

episodes.title: Pandemic Bonds

episodes.summary: A few years ago, the World Bank issued bonds designed to get cash to needy countries in the event of a pandemic. Sounds like a great idea! But the bonds haven't paid out yet and they may never.

episodes.title: The Most Vulnerable Workers

episodes.summary: Because of social distancing, the U.S. restaurant industry has entirely disintegrated with unimaginable speed, leaving its workers to face an uncertain future.

episodes.title: Our COVID-19 Indicators Of The Week
episodes.description: Zero and 27 are our indicators of the week. Zero (or nearly zero) is the Fed's new benchmark interest rate. 27 is the number of days that around half of small businesses in the U.S. can go without making money.
episodes.summary: Zero and 27 are our indicators of the week. Zero (or nearly zero) is the Fed's new benchmark interest rate. 27 is the number of days that around half of small businesses in the U.S. can go without making money.

episodes.summary: A short supply of test kits, staff and equipment have put the U.S. behind in terms of coronavirus testing. We talk to one healthcare worker about what's been limiting their coronavirus testing ability.

episodes.title: China's New Normal

episodes.summary: China appears to have stopped the spread of coronavirus within its borders. People there are now beginning to adjust to a new normal.

episodes.summary: Millions of people all across the world are now having to work from home. Including team Indicator. Today, a look at how this might change the way we work... and what it's like to skip the office.

episodes.title: Coronavirus: Update From Italy

episodes.summary: The coronavirus continues to roil global markets and economies - including here at home, where the markets took yet another dive. Today, we look at an epicenter of the virus outbreak: northern Italy.

episodes.summary: In 2017, rock climber Alex Honnold ascended Yosemite's rock formation El Capitan free solo, meaning without ropes or equipment. On today's show, we look at the economic lessons revealed by Honnold's extraordinary feat.

episodes.summary: The world has changed, and nearly two thirds of global wealth is human capital. Policymakers and politicians may not understand just what that means for global politics.

episodes.title: How Economists Do Valentines
